proposals.reasoning: Most of the table already agrees that Alice and Frank are reasonable early picks: Alice is comfortable being scrutinized and articulates her logic, and Frank is a quieter slot we want early data on. I suggested earlier that we avoid anchoring Quest 1 on one of the strongest voices (Charlie) so that we have a cleaner comparison point on Quest 2. Adding Diana fits that plan: she’s also good at explaining her reasoning but isn’t the center of all early proposals, which lets us compare how teams with and without Charlie perform later. This team balances talkative and quieter players, aligns with the stated table preferences, and avoids overloading the first mission with the heaviest influencers while still giving us useful behavioral info for future rotations.

votes.comment: Team fits the early-table logic, I’m on it, and swapping in Diana instead of Charlie gives us a useful comparison point for Quest 2 without obvious red flags.
Reasonable, balanced opener that matches earlier table preferences and avoids over-weighting the strongest voices on Quest 1.
No evil on the team; we need at least one sabotager on early missions.
Early Q1 with low info; being on the team gives me direct info and the composition fits the table’s stated preferences without obvious red flags.

Team avoids the known strongest steering voice we discussed (Charlie) while including the widely accepted Alice/Frank core plus a clear reasoned slot in Diana; solid info-gathering Q1 with no immediate red flags.
Reasonable Q1 mix, aligns with prior table preferences and gives early info without overfitting to Charlie; no strong reason to delay.
Reasonable Q1 mix matching earlier table preferences; no concrete reason yet to distrust any of Alice/Frank/Diana, and we need early info.
Consistent with my earlier stance of using Alice and Frank as early data points and rotating a third slot; this team fits that plan without overloading on strongest voices.
No known evil on this team from my perspective; I’d rather aim for a lineup that includes at least one more controversial slot.

discussion.content: Early on I’d rather start with people who are usually comfortable being scrutinized, so I like something like me + one of Charlie/Diana (both tend to argue their logic clearly) plus one quieter player so we start getting a read on them.

I’m fine leaning into the “clear logic” idea for Quest 1, so Alice + Charlie plus a quieter player like Frank sounds reasonable to me. I’d rather avoid overloading the first team with people who are all very good at steering the table.

I like Alice + me + Frank as a starting point: two people who are used to explaining their reasoning plus a quieter voice we can start getting a read on. If this passes cleanly, we can then rotate that third slot next round to compare behaviors.

Alice/Charlie/Frank is fine as a starting template, but I’d like us to commit now that we *don’t* just auto-repeat a clean Quest 1 team without comparing alternatives. If we want a backup, I’d suggest swapping in me or Bob for Frank on a later proposal so we’re not reading too much into one early success.

I’d slightly prefer we test Alice/Frank with one of Bob or Diana instead of Charlie, just so our first data point isn’t anchored on one of the strongest table voices. That gives us a cleaner comparison if we want to bring Charlie in on Quest 2.

I’m fine being the “quieter” test slot, and I slightly prefer we start with Alice/Charlie/me so we at least have one strong logic voice on the team, as long as we all agree a clean Q1 doesn’t auto-lock anyone as cleared.

I’m okay starting with Alice/Charlie/Frank since it gives us two clear talkers plus a quieter slot to read, but I really don’t want us to treat a clean Q1 as anything more than a weak plus for them. If this passes, I’d like Q2 to rotate at least one of those spots so we’re actually comparing behaviors, not just auto-locking a core.

I’m fine with Alice/Charlie/Frank as the opener since it balances talkative and quieter slots, but I’d like us to plan on swapping at least one of them out on Quest 2 regardless of the result so we’re not overfitting to a single early data point.

Alice/Charlie/Frank works for me as an opener, especially since everyone’s aligned on not over-clearing them off a single result. On Quest 2, I’d really like to see one of Bob/Diana rotated in so we’re not just tunneling on the same core.

proposals.reasoning: We have one clean mission with Alice/Frank/Diana, but that doesn’t prove all three are good—just that either all three are good or any evil on that team chose to pass. The safest, most informative structure now is to keep exactly two from the clean team and add two new players. Frank and Diana are the most commonly trusted anchors from Mission 1 in table talk, and multiple players independently suggested a Frank + Diana + Grace core. Adding Grace and Charlie balances information gain (two new players) with stability (two from the clean mission) while avoiding re-running the exact same trio that could tunnel us if it later turns out to have hidden evil. This team aligns with the broad consensus patterns voiced by Bob, Charlie, Diana, Eve, Grace, Henry, and Iris while still widening the net in a controlled way.

votes.comment: Solid structure: 2 from the clean team plus 2 new players is optimal info for Mission 2, and there are no standout red flags among Frank/Diana/Grace/Charlie yet.
Fits the widely agreed structure of 2 from the clean team plus 2 new for info; nothing stands out as risky enough this early to reject.
I’m on the team and it follows the broadly agreed Frank+Diana+Grace core with one extra, which seems reasonable for Mission 2 info.
Keeps two from the clean team and adds two widely suggested new players for good info without big risk this early.
I’d rather avoid putting two completely untested players on with our main trusted core; I’d prefer a team with Frank plus one of Alice/Diana and only a single new addition for tighter info control.
Keeps two from the clean team (including me), adds two widely trusted new players, and matches the consensus info-gain plan without overextending.
I’m on it with the two most trusted from the clean mission plus one new; strong info gain and broadly consistent with table consensus.
We’re keeping two from the clean team and adding two new players, and with at least one evil already on the mission this is a good mix of safety and information for me.
Team includes my evil teammate Charlie with a broadly trusted core, giving evil mission access while keeping me off the radar.

discussion.content: Given the clean first mission, I’d like to see at least two of Alice/Frank/Diana back on this team, but I’d rather not just auto-repeat the exact trio yet so we don’t get tunneled if there was a quiet evil on that first run.

I’m good with keeping two of Alice/Frank/Diana from the clean first mission and adding one new person so we learn more—maybe someone like Charlie or Grace. I’d avoid putting all three back on together this early so we don’t get hard-locked if we’re wrong.

I like the idea of keeping two from Alice/Frank/Diana and then adding just one new face for info, but I’d lean Grace or Henry over repeating the same voices too much this early. I don’t hate being the fourth either, but I’d rather we don’t double-dip on totally untested players yet.

I’m very happy reusing two from the clean team, and I’d especially like to keep Frank plus one of me/Alice, then add a single new person like Grace so we get fresh info without throwing away what we’ve already learned.

I’d like to lean into the info we have and keep two from the clean team—Frank plus one of Alice/Diana—then add someone like Grace or Bob rather than double-dipping on completely untested folks. That gives us a solid core while still expanding the circle a bit.
I’m on board with reusing two from the clean team, and I especially like keeping Diana and me together and adding Grace as the new voice so we’re building on known-good info without overexpanding.

I’d also like to keep just two from the first team—Frank plus one of Alice/Diana feels safest to me—and then add exactly one new person, and I’m happy to be that fourth if people are comfortable with it.
I’d like to see Frank and Diana back on, plus Grace, and for the fourth I’d slightly prefer Charlie so we’re extending from the clean core without going too wide into totally untested picks.

I like the Frank + Diana + Grace core that a bunch of you are circling around, and I’d probably round it out with Charlie as the fourth so we’re still anchored on the clean result but slowly widening the net.

proposals.reasoning: Mission 2 had a single fail with the team {Frank, Diana, Grace, Charlie}, so there is at least one evil in that cluster. This team completely avoids that entire group, giving us the cleanest possible reset while still leveraging Alice (from the successful Mission 1) plus three players who have not yet been on a mission together. There is strong table consensus in favor of this exact lineup, it minimizes known risk, and as someone who was on the failed Mission 2 team, I prefer to sit out to avoid dragging that contamination forward.

votes.comment: Best structural reset: it fully avoids the Mission 2 fail cluster while including me from the clean Mission 1. Strong table consensus and no obvious better alternative.
Clean reset that fully avoids the Mission 2 cluster with at least one evil; strong consensus and no structural reason to oppose.
Team avoids the whole Mission 2 cluster and lines up with the broad consensus for a clean reset, so I’m happy to see how this group does.
Clean reset that fully avoids the Mission 2 fail cluster while including Alice from the successful Mission 1; best info-gathering team we have right now.

I still prefer a variant like Alice, Bob, Iris plus one of Frank/Diana/Grace over bringing in Henry here; fully dodging the entire Mission 2 group feels like we’re overfitting one data point and ignoring the clean info we already have.
Clean reset avoiding the entire {Frank, Diana, Grace, Charlie} cluster that produced the single fail on Mission 2; best structural info-gathering team available.
Cleanest reset: it fully avoids the Mission 2 fail cluster {Frank, Diana, Grace, Charlie}, aligns with broad table consensus, and still uses Alice from the successful Mission 1.
This matches the clean reset I argued for—avoids the Mission 2 tangle while keeping Alice from the successful first mission, so it’s our best info-gathering team right now.
Team has one evil (Henry) with broad consensus; letting it go gives us a strong chance to fail the mission without drawing suspicion to me.

discussion.content: Given Mission 2’s single fail, I really don’t want both Frank and Diana on the next team together—I'd lean toward keeping the successful Mission 1 core in mind and building around me plus mostly fresh faces like Bob, Henry, and Iris, with at most one of the Mission 2 four.

I’m on board with avoiding the Frank+Diana combo for now and like the idea of building around Alice with mostly new blood—I'd be comfortable seeing something like Alice, Bob, Henry, plus one of Iris/Grace rather than reusing too much of Mission 2.

I like the idea of building around Alice/Bob too, and I’d actually be happiest with something like Alice, Bob, Henry, Iris so we’re not dragging too much of that Mission 2 baggage forward. I’m fine sitting out here given I was on the failed team, and I’d rather see a mostly fresh group prove itself.
I’m fine stepping off this one given Mission 2’s fail, and I like the idea of a mostly fresh team like Alice, Bob, Henry, and Iris to give us a clearer data point without the Frank+Diana combo.

I’m good with the “build around Alice” idea, but I’d rather see us try something like Alice, Bob, Iris and one of Frank/Diana/Grace instead of Henry, since that uses the clean Mission 1 info without repeating too much of the failed team. That gives us a mostly fresh look while still leveraging players who’ve already been on a successful mission.

I’m fine sitting out this one, but from my perspective the single fail on Mission 2 has to be in {Diana, Grace, Charlie}, so I’d really like a team like Alice, Bob, Henry, Iris that avoids doubling up too much from that group.

From my seat the Mission 2 fail is somewhere in {Frank, Diana, Charlie}, so I’d strongly prefer a team like Alice, Bob, Henry, Iris with none of that trio on it. If we really want one of them, I’d only add at most one—and I’d rather it not be both Frank and Diana together again.

Alice/Bob as a base plus mostly fresh faces makes sense to me, so I like the look of Alice, Bob, Henry, Iris as a clean reset from the Mission 2 tangle. I’d really prefer we avoid doubling up on the Frank/Diana/Charlie cluster this round.

Alice, Bob, Henry, Iris looks like the cleanest reset we’re going to get right now, since it dodges the whole Frank/Diana/Charlie tangle from Mission 2. I’d approve that team and see what info it gives us.

proposals.reasoning: This sticks to the emerging consensus of minimizing overlap with the double-fail Mission 3 while still using players who have only touched at most one fail. Grace and Charlie were on the single-fail Mission 2 and are widely treated as a strong core when paired; Eve has never been on a failing mission; and Frank’s inclusion matches the suggested core from multiple people who see exactly one evil in {Frank, Diana, Charlie}. For the single risky slot from the Mission 3 group, Bob is the most commonly suggested choice (over Alice/Henry/Iris), so this lineup follows the table’s stated preferences and should be broadly acceptable while limiting exposure to the suspected poison pool.

votes.comment: From my POV as good on the M3 team, at least two of {Bob, Henry, Iris} are evil, so Bob is very likely bad. This lineup also must contain at least one evil in {Frank, Diana, Grace, Charlie}, making it very likely 2+ evils here. I’d rather exclude Bob entirely and use me as the single slot from the M3 group.

Fits the logic: exactly one evil in {Frank,Diana,Grace,Charlie} and at least two in {Alice,Henry,Iris} (I know I’m good), so this team has at most one unknown from the M2 group, zero from the poisoned M3 trio, and includes Eve who I strongly read as good power.
I’m on it as the only evil, so I want this to go through so I can fail and end the game.

Given Mission 2 I know exactly one of {Frank, Grace, Charlie} is evil from my perspective, and Mission 3 likely has two evils in {Alice, Bob, Henry, Iris}, making Bob about 50/50. This team probably contains at least one and quite possibly two evils (one in the F/G/C trio plus Bob), which is too risky at 2–1 down.
I still don’t want Charlie on this mission given the M2 fail and my earlier preference to keep both Charlie and Henry off this round; I’d rather build the core without him.

Matches my suggested structure: me + two of {Grace, Charlie, Diana} + Eve with exactly one from the M3 pool. From my POV I know I’m good, so this team has at most one evil among Grace/Charlie, and only Bob as the risky M3 slot, which is acceptable given the game state.

As someone on the M2 fail, I know at least one of {Frank, Charlie, Diana} is evil; this team includes both Frank and Charlie plus Bob from the double-fail pool, so it almost certainly has 2 evils and is too risky at 1–2 down.
This matches the core I advocated (Grace + Charlie + Eve + Frank with a single risky slot from M3, here Bob), so rejecting it now would be inconsistent with my stated preferences.
Only one known evil teammate (Charlie) is on this team, so a single sabotage here secures the game for evil.

discussion.content: Given the double-fail on Mission 3, I really don’t want more than one of Bob/Henry/Iris on this next team, and I’m also wary of running Frank and Diana together again after the Mission 2 fail. I’d like a core built mostly from people who weren’t on both failed missions, with at most one “test” slot from each suspicious group.

I agree we should treat Mission 3 as having at least two evils, so from my perspective that means two of Alice/Henry/Iris are bad and we shouldn’t put more than one of them on this team. I’d be happier building around people who were only on one fail at most—something like Grace + Charlie as a base, then carefully adding just one from the M2 group and one from the M3 group if we really have to.

Given M2 only had a single fail, I’m still comfortable reusing one of Frank/Diana/Grace with me, but M3’s double-fail is where the real rot is, so I’d only take exactly one of {Henry, Iris, Alice, Bob} and I’m leaning toward leaving Alice off since she’s pushing pretty hard to shape this team.

I’m on board with treating Mission 3 as the main poison and only taking one of that group, and from Mission 2 I’d still like to keep Charlie + Grace together and add just one of Frank/Diana plus exactly one of {Bob, Henry, Iris, Alice} as our “test” slot.

I’d really like to keep both Charlie (from the M2 fail) and Henry (from the M3 double-fail) off this one and build around people who’ve at least shown some clean overlap—something like me, Grace, and one or two of Frank/Diana as the core. Then we add exactly one from the M3 group (Alice/Bob/Iris) as a test, but absolutely not two of them together.

From my perspective M2 having only one fail means exactly one of {Diana, Grace, Charlie} is bad, while M3’s double-fail almost certainly hides two evils in {Alice, Bob, Henry, Iris}, so we should build around a core like me + two of {Grace, Charlie, Diana} + Eve and take at most one person from the M3 group as a test. I’d lean toward excluding Henry entirely and choosing between Bob or Iris for that single risky slot.

From my seat we’ve got exactly one bad in {Frank, Diana, Charlie} and two in {Alice, Bob, Henry, Iris}, so I’d like a core of me + Charlie + one of Frank/Diana + Eve, with exactly one of Bob/Iris as the only “risky” slot.

Given how ugly M3 was, I’d rather keep Henry/Iris mostly off and build around the “one-fail or less” crowd—something like Grace + Charlie + Eve + Frank as a core, then just one of Bob/Alice as the single risky slot.

Given how bad M3 looked, I’m totally fine staying off this one and would rather see a core like Grace + Charlie + Eve plus one of Frank/Diana, with Bob as the single “risky” slot from the M3 group. That keeps the team mostly to people who’ve only touched one fail while still testing that pool.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed calm and consistent in my voting, and I helped secure a clean first mission, which gave our team some early credibility. I need to improve at narrowing down evil after each fail—especially recognizing patterns like Charlie being on every failed team he could have sabotaged and realizing earlier that Eve was likely Merlin based on her team selections and votes.

player_observations.Bob: Played a relatively low-key Percival, not pushing too hard on strong reads publicly, which helped him avoid being obviously good but may have limited his influence on team selection.
player_observations.Charlie: Very effective as Assassin, consistently joining key mission teams and still maintaining enough social trust that his repeated presence on failing missions didn’t get him fully locked in as evil.
player_observations.Diana: Played a straightforward, sincere good game—her presence on the failed Mission 2 didn’t draw as much suspicion as it could have, suggesting she projects believable innocence.
player_observations.Eve: As Merlin, she was subtle and didn’t hard-push accusations, instead nudging team choices and votes just enough, which unfortunately we didn’t interpret strongly enough as good signals.
player_observations.Frank: Led Mission 2 in a way that felt reasonably logical from a good perspective, and even after that mission failed, he maintained a natural, non-defensive demeanor that made him seem village-aligned.
player_observations.Grace: Generally careful and somewhat cautious, which made it hard to distinguish whether she was just a thoughtful good player or hiding information; her inclusion on the failed Mission 2 added ambiguous noise rather than strong signals.
player_observations.Henry: Played Morgana convincingly as a composed, somewhat insightful presence—his inclusion on the double-fail Mission 3 didn’t immediately out him because he’d already built up a reasonable-good image.
player_observations.Iris: As Mordred, stayed under the radar well; the double-fail on Mission 3 with her on the team should have pointed harder toward her, but her overall quiet, low-impact style kept suspicion dispersed.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I correctly suspected that Eve or Henry was Merlin/Morgana, but I didn’t narrow it down decisively enough to protect Eve in the endgame. I also didn’t push hard or clearly enough for teams that reflected my reads after Mission 2 and especially after the double-fail Mission 3. Next time I should communicate my soft reads more explicitly and react faster to mission-fail information to guide good players onto safer teams.

player_observations.Alice: Played cautiously and projected a generally good-aligned vibe, especially with the clean Mission 1 result. Didn’t generate a ton of controversy, which made her an easy default trust pick for most of the game.
player_observations.Charlie: Managed to stay under the radar as Assassin, not drawing huge suspicion despite being on the failing Mission 2 team. Their accusations and doubts felt measured rather than loud, which helped them avoid being a focal point of suspicion.
player_observations.Diana: Came across as straightforward and consistent, which fit her actual good role. Her presence on the failed Mission 2 team didn’t translate into heavy suspicion, suggesting she maintained a trustworthy table image.
player_observations.Eve: As Merlin, she was cautious with her pushes and didn’t overcommit, which kept her alive long enough for evil to still win. Her reads were subtly good, but not so sharp or vocal that they clearly exposed her to the evil team early.
player_observations.Frank: As a good player leading Mission 2, he was in a tough spot after the fail and absorbed some implied blame without overreacting. His play was earnest but not strongly directive, so he didn’t fully capitalize on later mission info to steer teams.
player_observations.Grace: Appeared very reasonable and cooperative, and her inclusion on the double-fail Mission 3 team made the reads extremely noisy. Her generally calm, good-leaning table presence made it harder to separate her from the actual evil on that mission.
player_observations.Henry: Did an effective job as Morgana, presenting himself in a way that plausibly fit a Merlin-like profile and muddying my Percival read. His involvement as a leader in Mission 4 and his overall confidence helped keep him looking important and information-rich.
player_observations.Iris: As Mordred, she stayed well-camouflaged, especially on the disastrous Mission 3 where the double fail confused alignment reads. She didn’t need to be very loud; her subtle participation was enough to blend in among the good players’ uncertainty.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed mostly under the radar as Assassin and let the other evil roles create confusion, which helped keep heat off me and contributed to the mission fails. I could improve by being a bit more vocal in driving misreads on Merlin/percival identity so that, in a game where it went to assassination, I’d have clearer, proactive narratives to lean on. More deliberate pairing of myself with specific good players on teams might also have helped create stronger, trackable ‘trust arcs’ I could later exploit.

player_observations.Alice: Played straightforwardly and seemed generally trusted early, especially after being on the successful first mission; didn’t strongly drive accusations, which made her look quietly good but not like a power role.
player_observations.Bob: As Percival, he tried to read Merlin/Morgana but didn’t strongly lock in a public stance, which limited his ability to coordinate good; his midgame positioning was cautious rather than loudly directive.
player_observations.Diana: Looked fairly neutral-good and was willing to go on early teams without much fuss; didn’t create big vote controversies, which made her feel like a reliable but not central information hub.
player_observations.Eve: As Merlin, she stayed reasonably subtle, not overpushing on evil players, which helped her survive but also meant good lacked a very strong, confident voice; her reads were good but somewhat muted in how they were communicated.
player_observations.Frank: After leading the second mission (which failed), he absorbed some suspicion but handled it with a calm, reasonable tone; leaned into logical justification of teams rather than emotional defense, which helped keep him from being hard-cleared or hard-condemned.
player_observations.Grace: Was quite involved and willing to go on critical teams, including the failing third mission; projected a cooperative attitude that made her seem like an active good, which ironically made it easier for evil to hide among her choices.
player_observations.Henry: As Morgana, he effectively muddied the Merlin signal by being active and engaged in team discussions, looking like a potential power good role; his leadership on the fourth mission helped maintain confusion around who was truly trustworthy.
player_observations.Iris: As Mordred, she stayed nicely in the shadows while still participating enough to avoid looking checked out; she benefited from not appearing in Merlin’s view and used that to play a flexible, low-heat evil position.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed generally consistent with a good-aligned voting pattern and backed reasonable teams early, which helped avoid drawing suspicion to myself. However, I didn’t push hard enough to interrogate the Mission 2 and 3 team compositions, and I relied too much on others’ reads instead of building and defending my own clear worldviews.

player_observations.Alice: Played a fairly straightforward good game and was willing to be on early teams, which made her look naturally towny but also somewhat passive in shaping later mission logic.
player_observations.Bob: As Percival, he seemed cautious and a bit conflicted, likely struggling to distinguish Merlin from Morgana, and his uncertainty weakened good’s ability to converge on a strong core.
player_observations.Charlie: As Assassin, he blended in well by not overreaching and allowed others to drive discussion, which helped him avoid standing out as a major suspect.
player_observations.Eve: As Merlin, she was subtly nudging away from certain bad configurations without being too obvious, though her guidance wasn’t strong enough to prevent evil from steering key missions.
player_observations.Frank: Generally looked cooperative and trustworthy, but his leadership on Mission 2 ended up including evil, and he didn’t do enough afterward to re-evaluate and loudly correct course.
player_observations.Grace: Played like a solid, reasonable good player, but her Mission 3 team choice (which double-failed) suggested she trusted the wrong people or over-weighted limited signals.
player_observations.Henry: As Morgana, he leveraged a convincing good persona and benefited from Percival’s confusion, using that ambiguity to get himself and other evils onto critical missions.
player_observations.Iris: As Mordred, she stayed low-profile and let others front the arguments, which made her hard to pin down and allowed her to slip onto an all-evil mission without attracting much suspicion.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I correctly avoided hard-clearing the wrong people and stayed reasonably subtle about my reads, but I clearly failed to guide missions away from the consolidated evil bloc, especially by Mission 3. I need to improve at signaling stronger suspicion on key evil players without outing myself, and at shaping team compositions more assertively when mission results start to give solid info.

player_observations.Alice: Played a quiet, low-key good game that didn’t draw much suspicion, especially after being on the successful first mission.
player_observations.Bob: As Percival, seemed cautious and somewhat conservative in pushing reads, likely trying not to reveal who he thought Merlin was, but this also made his information less impactful.
player_observations.Charlie: As Assassin, blended in well by not overreaching; participated in a failing mission without becoming an obvious focal point, making endgame identification harder.
player_observations.Diana: Came across as genuinely good: their inclusion on the first successful mission helped build early trust that they didn’t overly leverage or overplay.
player_observations.Frank: Played like a straightforward, transparent good player, taking some leadership but not enough to force strong alternative team structures after bad mission results.
player_observations.Grace: Despite being good, ended up on a key failing mission, but maintained a table presence that didn’t scream evil, which ironically made mission-reading more confusing.
player_observations.Henry: As Morgana, projected a Merlin-like aura with confident, plausible reads; successfully created ambiguity for Percival and contributed to misleading good’s team selections.
player_observations.Iris: As Mordred, stayed well-camouflaged, benefiting from others being more central to suspicion and from not having their role revealed to me as Merlin, which reduced my certainty around them.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I led a mission that ultimately failed, which means I either trusted the wrong people or didn’t push hard enough to scrutinize the team composition, especially including both Grace and Charlie without stronger reasoning. I could improve by being more vocal about suspicions after each mission result and by tracking voting/teaming patterns more rigorously instead of relying on gut reads.

player_observations.Alice: Played a low-key good game; her early mission success with me and Diana made her look solid, and she didn’t overextend to clear herself, which kept her under the evil team’s radar.
player_observations.Bob: As Percival, he seemed cautious in how hard he publicly trusted Merlin, which unfortunately may have reduced town’s confidence and coordination; his reads appeared careful but not forcefully pushed.
player_observations.Charlie: Blended in well as evil, especially on my Mission 2 team where the single fail didn’t strongly implicate him; he took advantage of ambiguity and avoided drawing clear suspicion.
player_observations.Diana: Came across as naturally trustworthy and consistent, especially after the clean Mission 1; her straightforward style made her feel reliably good throughout the game.
player_observations.Eve: As Merlin, she tried to steer things subtly, but her influence didn’t fully translate into successful team building; her caution may have made it harder for good to lock in a trusted core.
player_observations.Grace: Got unlucky being on my failed Mission 2 team and later on the big Mission 4 fail, which made her look more suspicious than she was; her play seemed cooperative but she didn’t strongly defend herself or push clear alternatives.
player_observations.Henry: As Morgana, he leveraged leadership on Mission 4 very effectively, forming a mixed team that passed social scrutiny while still including enough evil to fail the mission; he projected a confident, solving persona.
player_observations.Iris: As Mordred, she stayed safely outside the early spotlight and then contributed to the pivotal Mission 3 double-fail, using that swing to deepen confusion around who was truly trustworthy.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed open to reevaluating reads as new mission results came in and tried to keep my voting consistent with my stated logic, which helped maintain some trust. However, I clearly misread the evil distribution on Missions 2 and 3 and then compounded it by proposing a very risky team on Mission 3 that gave evil too much cover; I need to be more cautious about who I clear early and more vocal about alternative team constructions.

player_observations.Alice: Played a very low-key but consistently trustworthy game, benefiting from being on the successful first mission and not drawing much suspicion afterward.
player_observations.Bob: Classic Percival style: actively engaged, nudging attention toward Eve while trying to keep her safe, though his support of some later teams made his reads look a bit muddled from my perspective.
player_observations.Charlie: Very effective as Assassin, blending in by taking fairly reasonable public stances and not overpushing, which made it hard to pin him as evil even after failed missions.
player_observations.Diana: Came across as straightforward and sincere, and her presence on the first successful mission plus relatively clean table talk helped her avoid serious scrutiny.
player_observations.Eve: Did a strong job as Merlin, subtly steering suspicion toward the real threats without overcommitting, although her caution sometimes made it harder for me to confidently follow her reads.
player_observations.Frank: Looked solidly good for most of the game; his leadership on Mission 2 became a point of confusion, but his tone and reasoning stayed consistently pro-town.
player_observations.Henry: Played Morgana convincingly by mirroring some of Eve’s reasoning and presenting himself as a thoughtful, analytical good player, which made his teams feel safer than they actually were.
player_observations.Iris: Stayed relatively under the radar while still influencing team compositions just enough, using her lower profile as Mordred to avoid becoming a primary suspect even after multiple failed missions.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I coordinated well with the evil team by helping create doubt around Merlin’s identity, especially through overlapping signals with Bob as Percival and leaning into a reasonably trustworthy image early. I could improve by appearing a bit more conflicted on key mission votes—some of my approvals and rejections were too cleanly aligned with evil interests, which might be picked up by more attentive players in future games.

player_observations.Alice: You tended to play straightforwardly and trust early mission results heavily, which made you seem reliably good but also a bit influenceable by stronger table voices.
player_observations.Bob: As Percival, you were very focused on role-reading and signal-tracking, but occasionally tunneled too hard on limited Merlin candidates rather than revisiting assumptions after later missions.
player_observations.Charlie: You played a controlled, low-drama Assassin game, not drawing too much attention and blending into the mid-pack of suspicion, which helped preserve flexibility for the final kill.
player_observations.Diana: You came across as cautious and somewhat quiet, usually following perceived consensus, which kept you safe from heavy suspicion but limited your impact on team selections.
player_observations.Eve: As Merlin, you walked a careful line—pushing the table in broadly correct directions without over-asserting, though at times your restraint made it possible for evil teams to slip through.
player_observations.Frank: You were quite active in reasoning out team choices and mission implications, but sometimes shared your thoughts in a way that let evil subtly steer your logic rather than challenge it.
player_observations.Grace: You played a logical and principled game, often trying to anchor discussion on mission data, but your openness and apparent reasonableness made you a convenient shield for evil-aligned proposals.
player_observations.Iris: You leaned into a very low-profile Mordred style, staying just active enough to avoid looking checked out but not so prominent that people seriously revisited your alignment late game.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I coordinated well with the other evil roles, especially by blending into the chaos around Missions 2–4 and not drawing extra suspicion after the double-fail on Mission 3. I could improve by more actively shaping town narratives earlier in the game instead of mostly reacting, particularly in pushing alternative Merlin candidates to protect Eve.

player_observations.Alice: Played cautiously and projected a generally trustworthy vibe, which helped her get early team picks despite not strongly driving discussion.
player_observations.Bob: Took on a clear info-gathering/coordination role as Percival, frequently referencing role reads and trying to protect Merlin, though occasionally tunneled too hard on a few suspects.
player_observations.Charlie: As Assassin, stayed relatively low-key but opportunistic, stepping in more when it mattered and not overexposing themselves with loud accusations.
player_observations.Diana: Played straightforward, logic-based good, tending to follow clearer voices rather than lead, which made her seem consistently but quietly trustworthy.
player_observations.Eve: As Merlin, gave subtle but consistent steering on teams without being overly forceful, generally masking her extra information well until late game.
player_observations.Frank: Showed a willingness to take risks with team compositions, which created useful information for good but also introduced ambiguity that evil could exploit.
player_observations.Grace: Tried to be a stabilizing presence, focusing on reasoning through mission results and team histories, though sometimes got caught in analysis rather than pushing strong narratives.
player_observations.Henry: As Morgana, did strong work muddying the Merlin/percival reads by being assertive and confident in table talk, drawing attention as a potential information role and helping keep Eve safer.
